Although these are not areas we deal with, it makes it difficult to get on with education and training (which is what we do), when these needs are over riding. One student was referred to us by the Job Centre for a dyslexic support course. The training she did was really successful, but the student wasnt going to school due to a history of drug abuse. In practise shes not being helped with this, and therefore she cant rpogress with her learning. Another student was referred by MENCAP, and was doing well with his English and Maths. However he sometimes misses a week due to ill health, and once he needed to be hospitalised. It amounts to a creeping up of additional needs which interrupt learning. Were supposed to help students make decisions about their future, but this is difficult in such circumstances.

Our capacity is more limited and we cant always fit the client need to available project funing.
text: (DS7): the demand has increased but it has also become more complex. We have substantial unmet need (including up to 1,000 unmet calls per month). Our advice centre opening hours have been curtailed due to budget cuts - we dont know what demand is there outside opening hours. Our capacity is more limited and we cant always fit the client need to available project funing. It means in our case that alot of debt cases (that fall outside project limits) are being seen by volunteer advisors rather than staff. This isnt ideal - people can present with one issue (debt), but the length of time theyve faced it (due to austerity) bring other factors into play (suicidal thoughts; anxiety). The benefit system no longer offers safety nets and there is a general lack of support for people with mental health needs. Debt advisors now have suicide training. One of our clients with debts committed suicide and left a note for her debt advisor. Unfortunately the I, Daniel Blake scenario is very real. South Bristol Advice Service (no code attributed): we now run a regular form filling day to try and meet client deman, when we start numerous client journeys simultaneously in order to get them into the system. It can take weeks for their benefits to come through and sometimes we need to apply for emergency funds to meet immediate needs. People with poor mental health used to be accompanied by helath workers but this no longer happens so people need to do it for themselves. Many clients simply dont have the capacity and so disengage.

text: Yes. The organisation is youth-led, so they decide what they want to do and we try to accommodate this. Over the last two years weve been doing a lot of work around racial equality, before we were doing a lot around gender equality, which were still doing, but tensions that were seeing show that racism is the driver for this change. a) Weve always had more demand than we provide, but were seeing more demand, and with the funding we have now, were able to increase our reach, we have new premises which means we have more space, more young people and more staff. Training is providing opportunities and there are more choices for over 18s, we just guide advise and praise them. b) yes - theres been a rise in racism and right wing division. I should be clear, this has not just happened in the last two years, but since Brexit. The young people are also showing a lot of interest in climate change, but thats not in our remit. Theyre more vocal about homophobia and obstacles for those that are gay and muslim. HBV (Honour based violence) abuse weve seen more need. I dont think theres been a rise, but more people are coming forward. Theres safety in numbers, even if they dont feel comfortable discussing these issues out in their communities, they feel theyre listened to and are safe here. c) By hiring two new staff members who were former service users and who represent those using the service. Weve got stronger as weve got bigger and have better monitoring.
